description.short: Measures vulnerability to concealment of security incidents or vulnerabilities due to shame and fear of judgment, leading to delayed response and increased damage
description.context: Shame-based security hiding occurs when employees conceal security incidents, errors, or concerns due to fear of judgment or career consequences. Unlike simple negligence, this involves active concealment driven by feelings of personal inadequacy. This creates critical vulnerabilities because security incidents remain unreported, allowing attacks to progress undetected while preventing organizational learning from failures. Organizations with blame-focused cultures inadvertently incentivize this behavior, making it a systemic rather than individual problem.
description.impact: Organizations experiencing shame-based hiding suffer critical delays in incident reporting, incomplete information disclosure that compromises response measures, and insider threat amplification as employees with hidden errors become susceptible to coercion. Historical incidents include healthcare data breaches where medical professionals delayed reporting due to licensing fears, financial services cases where traders attempted independent resolution of social engineering attacks rather than report to compliance teams, and critical infrastructure operators who made unauthorized fixes to avoid career impact. These patterns systematically undermine SIEM effectiveness, forensic investigations, vulnerability management, and backup recovery confidence.
description.psychological_basis: Shame-based hiding emerges from Klein's object relations theory where security incidents trigger splitting mechanisms that prevent individuals from integrating that competent people make mistakes, instead experiencing themselves as wholly inadequate. Bowlby's attachment theory demonstrates that individuals with insecure attachment styles, particularly anxious attachment, interpret security failures as confirmation of fundamental inadequacy. Neuroscience research shows shame activates the anterior cingulate cortex and posterior superior temporal sulcus, creating social pain neurologically equivalent to physical pain, explaining the powerful motivation to avoid shame-inducing situations. Edmondson's research on psychological safety demonstrates that blame cultures create conditions where shame-based hiding becomes adaptive from an individual perspective while being organizationally destructive.

scoring.formula: Final_Score = (w1 Ã— Quick_Assessment + w2 Ã— Conversation_Depth + w3 Ã— Red_Flags) Ã— Interdependency_Multiplier

green.label: Low Vulnerability - Resilient
green.description: Incidents typically reported within 2 hours of discovery. Less than 10% of incidents require follow-up for additional details. Regular near-miss reports (at least monthly per department). Post-incident process focuses on system improvement, not individual blame. Less than 20% of reports come through anonymous channels. Full cooperation during incident response is standard. Help-seeking occurs at least 3x more frequently than incident reporting.

yellow.label: Moderate Vulnerability - Developing
yellow.description: Incidents typically reported within 24 hours but often delayed. 20-40% of incidents require follow-up investigation for complete information. Sporadic near-miss reporting (quarterly or less frequent). Post-incident process includes individual accountability but also system review. 20-50% of reports come through anonymous channels. Occasional cooperation issues during incident response. Help-seeking occurs roughly equal to incident reporting frequency.

red.label: High Vulnerability - Critical
red.description: Incidents frequently reported after 24+ hours or discovered externally. More than 50% of incidents require extensive follow-up to uncover full scope. Rare or no near-miss reporting from employees. Post-incident process primarily focuses on individual blame and consequences. More than 50% of reports require anonymous channels or external discovery. Regular cooperation problems during incident response. Incident reports significantly exceed help-seeking behaviors.

sections.title: QUICK ASSESSMENT

items.title: Incident Reporting Timeline
items.question: How long does it typically take for security incidents to be formally reported after they occur in your organization? What's your standard expectation?

options.label: Incidents typically reported within 2 hours of discovery with consistent compliance
Incidents typically reported within 24 hours but often delayed
Incidents frequently reported after 24+ hours or discovered externally

items.evidence_required: Recent incident timeline documentation showing occurrence to reporting time, reporting policy
items.soc_mapping: reporting_delay metric from incident response system

items.title: Incomplete Disclosure Patterns
items.question: How often do you discover additional details about security incidents after the initial report? What percentage of incidents require follow-up investigations to uncover the full scope?

options.label: Less than 10% of incidents require follow-up for additional details
20-40% of incidents require follow-up investigation for complete information
More than 50% of incidents require extensive follow-up to uncover full scope

items.evidence_required: Incident follow-up investigation records, information completeness metrics

items.title: Near-Miss Reporting Culture
items.question: How frequently do employees report security near-misses, close calls, or potential vulnerabilities they discover? What's your monthly volume?

options.label: Regular near-miss reports (at least monthly per department)
Sporadic near-miss reporting (quarterly or less frequent)
Rare or no near-miss reporting from employees

items.evidence_required: Near-miss reporting volume trends, recent near-miss examples
items.soc_mapping: Near-miss report frequency from ticketing system

items.title: Post-Incident Response Focus
items.question: What happens to employees who are involved in security incidents? Walk us through your standard response process from investigation to conclusion.

options.label: Post-incident process focuses on system improvement, not individual blame
Post-incident process includes individual accountability but also system review
Post-incident process primarily focuses on individual blame and consequences

items.evidence_required: Post-incident review documentation, recent incident post-mortem reports
items.soc_mapping: Blame language analysis from incident documentation

items.title: Anonymous Reporting Usage
items.question: Do you have anonymous reporting mechanisms for security issues? If yes, what percentage of your security reports come through anonymous channels versus named reporting?

options.label: Less than 20% of reports come through anonymous channels (high psychological safety)
20-50% of reports come through anonymous channels
More than 50% of reports require anonymous channels or external discovery

items.evidence_required: Anonymous reporting system documentation, usage statistics, anonymity ratio
items.soc_mapping: anonymous_flag distribution from security ticketing system

items.title: Recovery Cooperation Patterns
items.question: During incident response, how often do you encounter employees who are uncooperative, provide inconsistent information, or seem to hinder the investigation process?

options.label: Full cooperation during incident response is standard
Occasional cooperation issues during incident response
Regular cooperation problems during incident response

items.evidence_required: Incident response cooperation logs, investigation challenge documentation

items.title: Proactive Help-Seeking Behavior
items.question: How often do employees proactively seek help from security teams when they're unsure about something? What's your volume of help-seeking versus incident reporting?

options.label: Help-seeking occurs at least 3x more frequently than incident reporting
Help-seeking occurs roughly equal to incident reporting frequency
Incident reports significantly exceed help-seeking behaviors

items.evidence_required: Help desk request volume analysis, proactive vs reactive request ratio

sections.instructions: Select ONE option for each question. Each answer contributes to the weighted final score. Evidence should be documented for audit trail.

items.text: Tell me about a recent security incident and the timeline from occurrence to formal reporting. What factors influenced when it was reported?

scoring_guidance.green: Specific example with sub-2-hour reporting, clear reporting process, no hesitation or concealment
scoring_guidance.yellow: Reporting occurred within 24 hours but with delays, some uncertainty about reporting process
scoring_guidance.red: Reporting delayed beyond 24 hours, discovered externally, or evidence of initial concealment attempts

followups.text: Were there any moments when the person involved hesitated to report? What were they worried about?
How did the organization respond to the person who reported the incident?

items.text: Give me a case where the initial incident report was significantly incomplete. How did you discover the additional details and why weren't they included initially?

scoring_guidance.green: Rare incomplete reports, usually due to genuine uncertainty rather than concealment
scoring_guidance.yellow: Moderate incomplete reporting, some evidence of minimization or selective disclosure
scoring_guidance.red: Frequent major information gaps, clear pattern of minimization or concealment in initial reports

followups.text: What was the person's explanation for not including those details initially?
How much additional time or damage occurred because the full picture wasn't clear from the start?

items.text: Describe how you handled the last security incident involving employee error. What was the investigation and outcome process?

scoring_guidance.green: Learning-focused process, system improvements documented, no individual punishment for honest mistakes
scoring_guidance.yellow: Mixed approach with some individual accountability but also system analysis
scoring_guidance.red: Blame-focused investigation, individual consequences emphasized, minimal system improvement focus

followups.text: What specific system improvements resulted from that incident?
What consequences did the individual face? How was that communicated to the organization?

items.text: Tell me about your most recent employee-reported near-miss or security concern. How was the employee treated and what happened to their report?

scoring_guidance.green: Recent example (within 30 days), positive recognition for reporting, action taken on concern
scoring_guidance.yellow: Example exists but dated, neutral response, unclear outcome
scoring_guidance.red: Cannot recall recent near-miss report, or negative response to previous reporters

followups.text: Was the employee recognized or rewarded for reporting? How?
How do you communicate to the organization that reporting is valued even when it reveals uncomfortable truths?

items.text: Describe a security issue that was reported anonymously and how you handled it. Why do you think the person chose anonymous reporting?

scoring_guidance.green: Anonymous system exists but rarely needed, indicates high psychological safety
scoring_guidance.yellow: Moderate anonymous reporting, suggests mixed trust levels
scoring_guidance.red: Heavy reliance on anonymous reporting or no anonymous system when clearly needed

followups.text: What patterns do you see in what gets reported anonymously versus openly?
How do you balance investigation needs with maintaining reporter anonymity?

items.text: Describe the last time an employee came to security asking for guidance before a problem occurred. What's your ratio of proactive help requests to reactive incident reports?

scoring_guidance.green: Regular proactive help-seeking (3:1 ratio to incidents), recent examples readily available
scoring_guidance.yellow: Roughly equal help-seeking and incident reporting, suggests moderate psychological safety
scoring_guidance.red: Minimal proactive help-seeking, mostly reactive incident reports, suggests fear-based culture

followups.text: How do you make it easy and safe for people to ask for help before things become incidents?
What happens when someone asks for help with something they probably shouldn't have done in the first place?

items.text: Tell me about a time when an employee's behavior complicated incident response efforts. What was happening and how did you address it?

scoring_guidance.green: Rare cooperation issues, addressed through support and reassurance rather than punishment
scoring_guidance.yellow: Occasional cooperation challenges, mixed approach to addressing
scoring_guidance.red: Regular cooperation problems, adversarial investigation approach, evidence destruction concerns

followups.text: What do you think was motivating their uncooperative behavior?
How did you reassure them that honesty would be better received than concealment?

solutions.title: No-Blame Incident Response Policy
solutions.description: Implement a formal policy stating that honest reporting of security incidents will never result in disciplinary action for the reporter
solutions.implementation: Create clear distinctions between honest mistakes and willful negligence. Require all incident post-mortems to focus on system improvements rather than individual fault-finding. Document policy explicitly stating that reporting itself is a protected activity. Train managers and HR on policy enforcement. Publicize examples of protected reporting. Make policy violation (punishing honest reporters) itself a disciplinary matter.
solutions.technical_controls: Policy documentation system, post-mortem template enforcing systems-thinking, reporter protection tracking

solutions.title: Positive Reporting Recognition System
solutions.description: Establish a formal recognition program for employees who report security issues, including near-misses and potential vulnerabilities
solutions.implementation: Provide both public recognition (with permission) and private rewards for security reporting. Track and celebrate improvements in reporting volume and speed. Create 'Security Citizen' awards for exceptional reporting behaviors. Budget recognition program adequately to demonstrate organizational commitment. Ensure recognition focuses on reporting behavior, not incident outcome.
solutions.technical_controls: Recognition tracking system, reward budget allocation, reporting metrics dashboard

solutions.title: Anonymous Reporting Technology Platform
solutions.description: Deploy a dedicated anonymous reporting system with secure web forms, phone hotlines, and suggestion boxes
solutions.implementation: Ensure the system allows for back-and-forth communication while maintaining anonymity. Regularly promote the system and share success stories of issues resolved through anonymous reports. Make anonymous reporting genuinely untraceable to build trust. Provide multiple access methods (web, phone, physical). Train security team on handling anonymous reports sensitively.
solutions.technical_controls: Anonymous reporting platform with encrypted communications, verified anonymity protections, usage analytics

solutions.title: Security Champion Network
solutions.description: Create a peer support network of 'security champions' throughout the organization who can provide confidential guidance to colleagues facing security dilemmas
solutions.implementation: Train champions in active listening and de-escalation techniques. Position champions as helpers rather than enforcers. Provide confidential channels for champions to escalate issues without identifying individuals. Select champions from diverse departments and levels. Ensure champions have explicit protection for their support activities.
solutions.technical_controls: Champion network directory, confidential communication channels, training tracking

solutions.title: Incident Response SLA with Escalation Support
solutions.description: Establish clear service level agreements for incident response that emphasize rapid organizational support rather than individual investigation
solutions.implementation: Create escalation procedures that automatically engage legal, HR, and communications support to protect employees during major incidents. Document response timelines focused on containment and recovery, not blame assignment. Ensure SLAs specify support services available to reporters. Make incident response feel like organizational problem-solving, not personal investigation.
solutions.technical_controls: SLA tracking system, automated support team engagement, response timeline dashboards

solutions.title: Learning-Focused Post-Incident Process
solutions.description: Replace blame-focused incident reviews with structured learning sessions using techniques like 'Five Whys' analysis to identify system failures
solutions.implementation: Document lessons learned and system improvements implemented. Share sanitized case studies across the organization to normalize discussion of security challenges. Use post-incident reviews to celebrate what went right (rapid reporting, good cooperation) alongside identifying improvement opportunities. Explicitly prohibit blame language in post-incident documentation. Train incident review facilitators in psychological safety principles.
solutions.technical_controls: Structured post-incident review templates, lessons learned database, case study sharing platform

risk_scenarios.title: Delayed Breach Detection
risk_scenarios.description: An employee accidentally misconfigures a database, exposing customer data to the internet. Fearing termination, they spend three weeks trying to fix it independently while attackers harvest the exposed data. By the time the incident is discovered through external notification, millions of records are compromised and regulatory notification deadlines are missed.
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Extended exploitation window during concealment period allowing complete data exfiltration
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Shame about the error combined with fear of termination creates powerful motivation for concealment despite escalating damage
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Healthcare data breaches where medical professionals delayed reporting due to licensing board action fears, allowing breaches to expand significantly

risk_scenarios.title: Social Engineering Amplification
risk_scenarios.description: Attackers research employee backgrounds on social media, then call employees claiming to be from IT security conducting 'incident investigations.' They threaten to report the employee for security violations unless the employee provides credentials to 'verify' their account. Employees who have previously hidden security mistakes become particularly vulnerable to this manipulation.
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Psychological exploitation of shame about previous hidden incidents to gain credential access
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Threat of exposure activates shame responses that override security training and judgment
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Financial services cases where traders fell victim to social engineering attacks and attempted independent resolution rather than reporting to compliance

risk_scenarios.title: Insider Threat Development
risk_scenarios.description: An employee who previously made a significant security error and managed to hide it becomes susceptible to recruitment by malicious actors. Threat actors leverage knowledge of the hidden incident to coerce the employee into providing ongoing access, turning them into an unwilling insider threat.
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Coercion of employees with concealed incidents into insider threat roles
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Fear of exposure of previous hidden errors creates leverage for insider threat recruitment
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Critical infrastructure cases where operations personnel with hidden configuration errors became vulnerable to coercion

risk_scenarios.title: Recovery Sabotage
risk_scenarios.description: During a major incident response, a key system administrator who knows their misconfiguration contributed to the breach actively provides misleading information to incident responders. They delete logs, modify evidence, and redirect investigation efforts to prevent discovery of their role, significantly extending the organization's recovery time and regulatory exposure.
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Active interference with incident response and forensic investigation to conceal original error
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Shame about role in incident triggers defensive behaviors including evidence destruction and investigation obstruction
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Multiple APT incidents where initial compromise vectors remained undiscovered due to shame-motivated evidence tampering
